9.00.text:
Here is a selection of swimming costumes
I have made up from my Sewing Pattern Number 206

14.84.text:
The secret to making great swimming costumes 
is to buy the right sort of fabric

19.94.text: and to learn appropriate sewing techniques

23.30.text:
Choosing the right stitch for stretch and appearance
is the key

28.24.text: Here I have used a cover stitch machine

30.26.text:
but I will show you that you can achieve identical
results on a sewing machine, using a twin needle

36.40.text:
The double stitching encases the elastic
around the leg edges

40.96.text: and gives a really neat finish

43.28.text: and the gusset lining is also neatly encased

47.58.text: There are some wonderful prints available for swimwear

51.94.text: You can’t go wrong with stripes and spots for the beach

56.56.text: Of course plains will always be popular

63.50.text: The back here is cut higher than the pattern

66.38.text: You can also make it a lot lower if you like

69.78.text:
And of course black
Everyone needs a black swimming costume

74.50.text:
So get yourself some great swimwear fabric
and try out my classic Swimming Costume Pattern

81.88.text:
This is a PDF Sewing Pattern
for angelakane.com members

85.82.text:
Swimming costumes look great
made up with contrasting fabrics

94.22.text: These dots would be wonderful for a two piece

97.52.text: I will be adding two piece swimwear patterns soon

104.36.text: I’ve been a fan of this shade of green for a while

107.28.text:
and this will go well with garments
I already have in my collection

111.54.text: Lycra is probably the most used fabric for swimwear

115.48.text:
It is seriously stretchy but it is also flattering
as it holds you in and gives you good shaping

124.14.text: Lycra stretches the same amount in both directions

127.98.text: and it usually stretches to a maximum of 1½ times

132.94.text:
Test your fabric by picking up a single layer
in the middle not along an edge

139.86.text: If you measure 12” it will stretch to 18”

157.92.text: Make sure you are testing along the straight grain

162.22.text: This geometric print is a good guide for a grain line

167.92.text: The maximum stretch is the same

173.36.text:
This colour is delicious
I’m looking forward to making it up

178.78.text:
One metre or one yard of fabric is ample
for all sizes and in the most of the usual widths

184.76.text:
You’ll probably have some over in the width
to make accessories

190.66.text: Here is my Sewing Pattern Number 206

193.40.text:
You can download it in sizes 6-22 and it’s very easy
to print on A4 or Letter sized paper

202.30.text: Always print off the test page first and measure the grid

206.58.text: which must be 1”x1” measuring across the whole page

216.72.text: This pattern has just three pieces

225.02.text: My patterns really are the easiest you will find online

228.70.text: Because I draft separate layouts for both A4 and Letter

232.52.text: you won’t find those annoying lining up marks

239.08.text: There is no trimming and very little waste

242.50.text: each size is drafted separately as well

245.48.text: Columns have numbers and rows have letters

259.36.text: Use some weights and tape together

264.78.text:
It takes less than five minutes
to assemble an Angela Kane PDF Sewing Pattern

278.18.text: So here is the complete sewing pattern

282.24.text: This pattern has the seam allowance included

285.38.text:
If you prefer to work with a net pattern
then just cut along the stitching lines

293.30.text: So here are the three pieces

298.64.text: The Gusset Lining, the Back Piece and the Front

305.98.text:
You can modify the back neckline
Make it very low for the beach

320.34.text: Because of the nature of Lycra

322.56.text:
the length of this pattern is reduced
to 85% of the true body measurement

331.04.text: The gusset lining is cut without seam allowance

338.54.text:
When the back and front are stitched together
at the crotch seam

343.08.text: The gusset lining is basted in place

347.06.text:
and is neatly encased
in the seam allowance of the leg

356.62.text: We can now cut out the fabric

359.28.text: I have laid out my pieces across the width

362.16.text: I use weights rather than pins. It’s much quicker

365.44.text:
Anything will do
Here I’m using curtain weights and washers

369.72.text: The length is running this way

372.12.text:
This is your straight grain guide
which is parallel to the selvedge

381.38.text: Clip these notches as you cut out

383.80.text:
You can use the notches as a guide
for matching larger patterns

393.42.text:
Don’t worry to much about matching
a print such as this

400.18.text:
For the gusset lining
use something like cotton T-shirt jersey

420.66.text: Remember we cut this out without seam allowance

427.26.text:
Once your pattern is cut out
don’t forget to mark all your notches

435.96.text:
Just one snip halfway into the seam allowance
is all that is needed

441.24.text: Lycra is very easy to sew

443.86.text:
and although you will see most commercial garments
sewn together with overlocking and cover stitch

448.66.text:
Your regular sewing machine can produce identical
or even better results if you have the know how

456.94.text:
If you are stitching Lycra for the first time
it is worth using up some off cuts to test your stitches

463.60.text: This is my preferred stitch for seams in Lycra

467.48.text:
Two rows of machine stitching with a slight zigzag
and then trimmed afterwards

478.60.text: It’s very neat and there is plenty of stretch

484.34.text:
Here we have one row of slight zigzag
and a full zigzag next to it

489.54.text:
This is useful if you think your jersey
is loosely stitched  and prone to running

501.30.text:
In practice of course you would use
a matching thread for these seams

513.06.text:
For turnings and for encasing the elastic
around the legs, the twin needle is ideal

521.90.text: Here I have used wooly nylon for the bobbin thread

526.30.text:
This is also know as Bulk Looper Thread
and does what it says

531.40.text: It softens and covers raw edges well when overlocking

536.36.text: but is also great with twin needle stitching

540.50.text:
Try hand winding the wooly nylon on the bobbin
for best results

550.58.text: And here is a turning using just the zigzag stitch

554.10.text: and ordinary thread in the bobbin

556.40.text: This stitch works really well on swimwear

559.78.text:
Perhaps it is a little less
like a commercially made garment

566.26.text: And again trim the seam after sewing for best results

570.54.text: You can also use wooly nylon in the bobbin

573.56.text: So that is an insight into your choices for stitching

577.08.text:
It is always worth while testing stitches
threads and sewing machine needles

581.98.text: so that you will have trouble free sewing

591.12.text: We have here the Front and Back

594.24.text: The Front is longer at the crotch

597.00.text: The first seam to stitch is this crotch seam

600.70.text: It’s a short seam and you probably don’t need to pin it

607.46.text: Use ball point pins with jersey. It does make a difference

616.06.text: I shall use my preferred stitch

620.46.text: The two rows of narrow zigzag

635.22.text:
It’s not so necessary to press the seams
on this sort of jersey

646.62.text: Trim the seam to a millimetre or so from the stitching

661.58.text: Now is the time to add the crotch lining

688.12.text:
The raw edges will be neatly encased
within the leg turnings

697.18.text:
We don’t normally need to neaten these edges
as this jersey will not ravel

702.54.text:
If you have a basting stitch
on your sewing machine, use it

706.60.text: I find it fixes much more securely than hand basting

717.38.text: Right that will stay in place while we get on

762.38.text: So again two rows of narrow zigzag

779.02.text: and trim back to a millimetre or so from the stitching

791.28.text: So the seams are stitched and trimmed

797.12.text:
Next we are going to finish
the neckline and armhole edges

803.84.text:
Although I’m not pressing these seams, it’s usual
to make sure that seams lie towards the back

816.42.text:
I’m going to use a 4mm twin or double needle
for stretch fabrics

827.94.text:
For an extra neat finish, clip the seam allowance
at the seam line, just short of the first row of stitching

843.36.text: and have the seam allowances lie in opposite directions

849.54.text: This does wonders to reducing bulk when seams cross

854.84.text: I am machine basting the neckline ⅝” turning in place

859.80.text:
Later on you may be happy to skip this step and
sew the turning from the right side without the basting

866.64.text:
Doing it this way makes it much easier to sew
around the curves and guarantees good results

873.38.text: ry not to stretch as you stitch

875.38.text:
If you haven’t got a basting stitch
on your sewing machine

878.84.text: use the longest stitch and loosen the tension a little

914.14.text:
As you approach the curve of the neckline
you can stretch a little

918.46.text: so that the seam allowance remains flat as you sew

921.76.text: Do your best to keep the seam width even

925.08.text: So continue all the way round

927.46.text: Keep your basting an even distance from the fold

930.52.text:
We will be using this as a guide
when we sew from the right side

964.36.text:
We are going to stitch either side of the basting
using the twin needle

972.88.text:
Check your sewing machine manual
for twin needle threading

977.76.text: It’s best to start stitching in an inconspicuous place

981.68.text:
For the neckline
I usually start just behind the shoulder seam

986.10.text: and just behind the side seam for the underarm

1009.60.text: Guide the basting into the centre of the foot

1022.58.text:
And I finish stitching by overlapping an inch or so
which is enough to stop the stitches coming undone

1031.68.text:
You can use the useful product Fray Check
or sew in ends if you prefer

1041.92.text:
The neckline and armholes are stitched
so take out the basting

1046.50.text:
That’s not such a difficult job
as the twin needle stitching lies either side

1051.62.text: so the basting doesn’t get caught up

1054.80.text: Tweezers are really useful for this job

1060.72.text:
Once the basting is removed trim back the seam
allowance to a millimetre or so from the stitching

1067.50.text:
Just slide your scissors along
without trying to get too close

1071.66.text:
You will find that after washing this edge will look
less and less like a raw edge

1075.80.text: as the jersey is inclined to roll

1082.04.text:
If you look at manufactured swimming costumes
and also underwear stitched using cover stitch

1087.28.text: you will find that this cut edge finish is used

1090.60.text:
although commercial machines
cut off the allowance during the sewing process

1111.58.text:
So that is the neckline and armholes finished
to a very high standard

1116.62.text: A nice finish on the inside

1130.58.text: The curved neckline lies nice and flat

1140.80.text: All the qualities needed in great swimwear

1159.78.text: Firstly, here is this specialist swimwear elastic

1163.22.text: It is supposed to be chlorine and seawater resistant

1166.68.text:
Personally I don’t much like working with it
It’s rather too wide

1171.58.text: so I will leave this for another video

1174.98.text: I find regular elastic holds up very well

1178.72.text: I’ve used this narrow Prym elastic for swimwear before

1182.90.text: This ordinary elastic from John Lewis is fine

1186.56.text:
I like this flesh colour
In fact it feels softer than the white

1192.62.text:
I don’t know why that is
as they are labelled the same

1199.92.text: So this is the one I am going to use

1210.86.text: I find the easiest and neatest way to apply elastic

1214.46.text: is to machine baste it in place

1227.32.text:
and at the same time
stretching the elastic a little as you go round

1240.38.text:
This makes topstitching with the twin needles
from the right side very easy

1246.96.text: So at the sewing machine and using a basting stitch

1250.68.text: place the elastic in position just before the seam line

1263.24.text: Fold over the ⅝” seam allowance

1276.30.text: Take a couple of machine stitches to anchor the elastic

1283.08.text:
then fold in the seam allowance and baste
stretching the elastic slightly

1293.80.text:
You should try and stretch the elastic
more around the back of the leg

1298.18.text: and only very slightly along the leg front

1315.62.text: Push the elastic against the fold as you sew

1397.70.text: Cut the elastic leaving a little extra

1420.90.text:
When you get close to the starting point
trim the elastic so that it just overlaps the beginning

1431.54.text: tucking it inside the seam allowance

1461.24.text:
Take advantage of your free arm sewing machine
if you have one

1465.72.text:
Slipping the leg over the free arm
does make it a little easier

1483.44.text:
Getting started with the elastic in position
is the hardest bit

1515.92.text:
Once you have it anchored with a few stitches
you are away

1523.50.text:
So again, remember to stretch the elastic a little more
along the back leg than the front leg section

1593.70.text: That is the second leg done

1600.76.text:
So the for the final stitching
using the twin needle, sew as before

1610.94.text: feeding the basting stitch into the centre of the foot

1618.76.text: Start your stitching at the crotch seam

1627.28.text: Stretch the elastic as you stitch

1645.50.text: As you reach the end trim your threads

1653.84.text: and try and sew exactly over the beginning stitches

1691.06.text:
Returning to the flat bed
I’m stitching around the other leg

1794.18.text: All that is left to do now is to remove the basting

1811.78.text:
Once the basting is removed, trim back the seam
allowance to a millimetre or so from the stitching

1823.44.text:
The swimming costume is finished
and I’m very pleased with it

1832.90.text:
The basting stages may be a bit of a chore
but the result is worth it

1841.98.text: If you wanted to line this costume, use Lycra lining

1846.98.text: Treat the two layers as one and make in the same way

1854.68.text:
A racing back version would be
a nice addition to my pattern collection
